segments.text: Okay, I need to translate this Python code into C. Let me look at the Python code first.
segments.label: code_analysis

segments.text: The Python code reads a line of input, splits it into four integers, calculates some differences, then computes x3, y3, x4, y4, and prints them. So the first step is to read the input. In Python, they use input().split(" ") to get the four numbers.
segments.label: code_analysis

segments.text: In C, I'll need to read from stdin using scanf. But I have to make sure that the input is read correctly. Let's see. The input is four space-separated integers. So in C, I can use scanf("%d % d % d % d", &x1, &y1, &x2, &y2);. That should work. Then, compute DIF1 and DIF2.
segments.label: code_analysis

segments.text: Those are x2 - x1 and y2 - y1. Then calculate x3 as x2 - DIF2, y3 as y2 + DIF1. Similarly for x4 and y4.
segments.label: mental_execution

segments.text: Those calculations are straightforward, just arithmetic operations. So in C, I can assign those variables similarly. Printing the result: in Python, they concatenate the string with spaces. In C, I'll use printf with format specifiers. So the print statement becomes printf("%d % d % d % d\n", x3, y3, x4, y4);. Wait, let me check the order.
segments.label: language_mapping

segments.text: The Python code prints x3, y3, x4, y4. So in the C code, the printf should have the variables in that same order. Now, putting it all together.
segments.label: code_analysis

segments.text:
The variables in C need to be declared as integers. So the code structure would be:

Include stdio.h for input/output functions. Main function: int main() { ... } Inside main: Declare variables x1, y1, x2, y2, dif1, dif2, x3, y3, x4, y4. Read the input using scanf.
segments.label: high_level_plan
bug_fixing
